channel.title: World
channel.description: The Washington Post World section provides information and analysis of breaking world news stories. In addition to our world news and video, Post World News offers discussions and blogs on major international news and economic issues.

item.title: A timeline of conflict on the Israel-Lebanon border
item.dc:creator: Sammy Westfall, Victoria Bisset, Niha Masih
item.description: For decades, Israel has seen Hezbollah as a major threat. But through rounds of conflict and war, it has not won a decisive victory.

item.title: Live updates: Israel’s invasion of southern Lebanon escalates fight against Hezbollah
item.dc:creator: Rachel Pannett, Niha Masih
item.description: The incursion, described by Israel as “limited” and “targeted,” follows weeks of stepped-up attacks against the militant group and the killing of its longtime leader.

item.description: The IDF said the raids were “limited, localized, and targeted,” and aimed at destroying Hezbollah targets and pushing fighters away from the Israeli border.

item.title: The G.O.A.T. of a Canadian half marathon was — an actual goat
item.dc:creator: Kyle Melnick
item.description: Joshua the goat escaped from a pumpkin patch and joined his Canadian town’s half marathon. He received a medal for finishing.

item.title: U.S. sends more troops, warplanes to Middle East as bulwark against Iran
item.dc:creator: Dan Lamothe
item.description: With Israel’s killing of Hezbollah leader Hasan Nasrallah, the Pentagon is bracing for retaliatory action from Tehran’s network of militias and militant groups.

item.title: Rocket attack reported on U.S. complex at Baghdad airport
item.dc:creator: Dan Lamothe, Mustafa Salim

item.title: Mexico’s first female president has stunning power. Can she use it?
item.dc:creator: Mary Beth Sheridan
item.description: Claudia Sheinbaum takes office with the largest mandate since Mexico became a democracy a quarter-century ago. She faces concerns about the economy, crime and a predecessor who might not go away.

item.title: Italy and Switzerland to redraw Alpine border due to melting glaciers
item.dc:creator: Kelsey Baker, Kasha Patel
item.description: Melting glaciers changed the topography of a roughly 330-foot-long segment of the border between Italy and Switzerland.
